title: Cooking Project — Trail Mix
description: The child measures, combines, and mixes ingredients to create a simple trail mix. This cooking project introduces measuring cups and following a recipe with multiple steps.
instructions:
1. Wash hands. Review the recipe card together.
2. Name each ingredient: raisins, pretzels, cereal, sunflower seeds, dried cranberries.
3. Demonstrate measuring 1/2 cup of raisins and pouring into the mixing bowl.
4. Child measures each ingredient, leveling the measuring cup.
5. Stir gently with a wooden spoon.
6. Scoop trail mix into a small bag or cup for snack.
7. Clean up: wipe table, wash bowl and spoon, put ingredients away.

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange all ingredients in small bowls on a tray. Place the recipe card where the child can see it. Have the mixing bowl and measuring cup ready.

slides.text: 'Today we are following a RECIPE to make trail mix! A recipe tells us exactly what to put in and how much.' Read the recipe card together.
Demonstrate: scoop raisins into the 1/2 cup measure. 'See how I fill it up and then level the top? That is how we measure carefully.'
'Pour it into the big bowl. Now your turn! Measure 1/2 cup of pretzels.' Guide leveling if needed.
'Keep going through the recipe — cereal, sunflower seeds, cranberries. Check off each ingredient on the recipe card as you add it.'

slides.prompt: Measure and add all the remaining ingredients. Stir everything together gently. Scoop your trail mix into a bag for snack time!

slides.text: Enjoy your trail mix! Wash the bowl, spoon, and measuring cup. Wipe down the table. Put ingredient containers away.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child follow a multi-step recipe card, measure with a 1/2 cup, and clean up independently?

parent_notes: Cooking is one of the most complete Montessori practical life activities — it involves sequencing (following a recipe), math (measuring), reading (recipe card), fine motor skills (pouring, stirring), and care of environment (cleanup). A picture recipe card is essential at this age: draw or print images of each ingredient next to the amount. Let the child check off each step. Trail mix is ideal because there is no cooking involved, and the child can adjust ingredients to taste. This builds toward more complex recipes in later weeks.

title: Phonograms — ai and oa
description: Introduction to the long vowel phonograms 'ai' (as in rain) and 'oa' (as in boat). The child learns that two letters together can make one long vowel sound.
instructions:
1. 'You know that letters make sounds. Sometimes TWO letters work together to make ONE sound.'
2. Present the 'ai' sandpaper phonogram card. Trace: 'This says /ay/ as in rain.'
3. Three-period lesson for 'ai': 'Show me ai. What does this say?'
4. Present 'oa': 'This says /oh/ as in boat.'
5. Three-period lesson for 'oa'.
6. Build words with moveable alphabet: rain, tail, mail, boat, coat, road.
7. Child reads each word after building.
materials_needed: Picture cards: rain, tail, mail, boat, coat, road

slides.heading: Phonograms
slides.subheading: ai and oa — Long Vowel Teams

slides.setup_instructions: Have sandpaper phonogram cards ready. Prepare picture cards to match words that will be built.

slides.text: 'Remember sh, ch, and th? Those were two letters making one sound. Today we learn two MORE! These make long vowel sounds.'
Trace 'ai' on the sandpaper card. 'This says /ay/. When you see a-i together, they say /ay/ like in RAIN.' Child traces three times.
Three-period lesson: 'This is ai.' 'Show me ai.' 'What does this say?' Then present 'oa': 'This says /oh/ like in BOAT.'
'Let us build words! R-AI-N. The ai says /ay/.' Build: rain, tail, mail. Then: boat, coat, road.

slides.prompt: Build three 'ai' words and three 'oa' words with the moveable alphabet. Read each one aloud. Match them to the picture cards.

slides.text: 'Two letters can work as a team! ai says /ay/ and oa says /oh/. You will see these in many books!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the sounds of 'ai' and 'oa' and read at least 3 words containing each phonogram?

parent_notes: Phonograms (also called digraphs or vowel teams) are a key step in reading development. The child has already learned consonant digraphs (sh, ch, th). Now we introduce vowel teams where two vowels together make a long vowel sound. The rule 'when two vowels go walking, the first one does the talking' applies here: in 'ai' you hear the long /a/, in 'oa' you hear the long /o/. Present only two phonograms at a time to avoid confusion. The sandpaper cards provide the tactile input that reinforces memory. Building words immediately shows the child how phonograms function in real reading.

title: Golden Bead Multiplication — Introduction
description: The child discovers multiplication as 'taking the same quantity several times.' Using golden beads, they build the same number on multiple trays and combine them to find the product.
instructions:
1. 'We have learned to add different numbers. Today we will do something new — multiplication!'
2. 'Multiplication means taking the SAME number MORE THAN ONCE.'
3. Give the child 3 trays. 'Put 12 on each tray: 1 ten bar and 2 units.'
4. 'We have 12, three times! 12 taken 3 times.'
5. Combine all beads: 3 ten bars + 6 units = 36.
6. '12 taken 3 times gives us 36! That is multiplication.'
7. Repeat with 11 taken 4 times (44), then 13 taken 2 times (26).

items: Golden beads: units, ten bars, hundred square
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the floor mat. Place golden beads in the bank area. Have 3-4 small trays ready for the child to build identical quantities.

slides.text: 'In addition we put DIFFERENT numbers together. Multiplication is different — we take the SAME number again and again!'
'Let us take 12, three times. Build 12 on this tray: 1 ten bar and 2 units.' Child builds. 'Now build 12 again on this tray. And again on the third tray.'
'We have 12... 12... 12. Three groups of 12! Now bring them all together.' Combine: count ten bars (3), count units (6). 'That is 36!'
'12 taken 3 times equals 36. That is MULTIPLICATION!' Place numeral cards: 12 x 3 = 36.

slides.prompt: Try 11 taken 4 times. Build 11 on four trays. Combine them. What do you get? Then try 13 taken 2 times.

slides.text: 'Multiplication is taking the same number many times and combining. You just multiplied with golden beads!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build identical quantities on multiple trays and combine them to find the product?

parent_notes: Montessori introduces multiplication concretely long before memorizing times tables. The key language is 'taken X times' rather than 'times' or 'multiplied by' initially. The child physically builds the same quantity on separate trays (representing groups), then combines them. This makes multiplication visible as repeated addition. Do not rush to symbols — let the child experience many rounds of building, combining, and counting. The golden beads make exchange natural: if 14 taken 3 times yields 12 units, the child already knows to exchange 10 units for a ten bar. This builds directly on their addition with exchange experience.

title: Puzzle Map — Europe
description: Introduction to the Europe puzzle map. The child learns to identify the continent of Europe and several major countries by their shapes and positions.
instructions:
1. Review the world puzzle map: 'Which continent is this?' Point to Europe.
2. Present the Europe puzzle map. Remove all pieces.
3. 'Europe has many countries close together. Let us learn a few.'
4. Start with large, distinctive pieces: France, Spain, Italy, United Kingdom, Germany.
5. Name each as you place it: 'This is Italy. See how it looks like a boot?'
6. Three-period lesson for 3-4 countries.
7. Child rebuilds the puzzle independently.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the Europe puzzle map on the mat. Have the world map nearby for context. Keep the control map face-down until needed.

slides.text: 'We have explored North America and South America. Today we travel across the ocean to EUROPE!' Show Europe on the globe and world map.
Remove all pieces. 'Europe has many countries — more than the other maps we have done! Let us start with a few big ones.'
'This is ITALY — see how it looks like a boot kicking a ball? And this is SPAIN — it is next to the ocean.' Place each piece as you name it.
'This is FRANCE — it is right next to Spain. And across the water, this island is the UNITED KINGDOM.' Place Germany: 'GERMANY is in the middle.'

slides.prompt: Three-period lesson: 'Show me France.' 'Where is Italy?' 'What country is this?' Then try rebuilding the whole puzzle!

slides.text: 'You learned countries in Europe! Next time we will learn about the people and cultures in these places.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and place at least 4 European countries on the puzzle map?

parent_notes: The Montessori geography curriculum progresses from the whole (globe) to parts (continents) to details (countries). Europe has many small pieces, which can be challenging. Start with the 4-5 largest and most recognizable countries. Italy's boot shape is a wonderful mnemonic. Do not expect mastery of all countries — this is an introduction. The child will return to this map many times. You can extend this work by looking at pictures of these countries, trying foods from each culture, or listening to music. The control map (with country names printed) serves as a self-correcting reference.

title: Read-Aloud: Stone Soup (retold by Marcia Brown)
description: A classic folktale about resourcefulness, sharing, and community. Three soldiers convince a village to contribute ingredients for a communal soup, connecting to the cooking theme.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is an old story called Stone Soup. What do you think stone soup is?'
2. Read aloud with expression, pausing for predictions.
3. After the villagers start contributing: 'Why do you think they changed their minds?'
4. Discuss: 'Was it really the stone that made the soup taste good? What made it good?'
5. 'Have you ever shared something and ended up with more than you started with?'
6. Optional: make a simple soup together, starting with a clean stone!
materials_needed: Stone Soup by Marcia Brown (or any retelling)

items: Optional: a clean stone as a prop
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. If using a stone prop, wash it thoroughly.

slides.text: Show the cover. 'This is a very old story that people have told for hundreds of years! It is called Stone Soup. Can you really make soup from a stone?'
Read aloud. When the soldiers start the soup: 'They are cooking a stone! Do you think it will taste good?' Pause as villagers contribute ingredients.
After reading: 'Was the stone the real secret? What actually made the soup delicious?' Guide toward: everyone sharing a little made something wonderful.

slides.prompt: Draw your favorite part of the story. Or draw what YOU would add to the soup if you were a villager. Label your drawing if you can.

slides.text: 'When everyone shares a little, we end up with something amazing. That is the lesson of Stone Soup!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the basic story and explain the message about sharing and community?

parent_notes: Stone Soup connects beautifully to the cooking practical life work this week. The story teaches about generosity, community, and resourcefulness without being preachy. There are many versions — Marcia Brown's is the classic, but Jon Muth's and Heather Forest's versions are also excellent. The deeper Montessori connection is to grace and courtesy and community living. After reading, you might actually make a simple vegetable soup together, ceremonially adding a clean stone to the pot. This makes the story come alive and gives another cooking experience.

title: Geometric Cabinet — Circle, Square, Triangle Drawers
description: The child explores the geometric cabinet drawers containing circles, squares, and triangles of graduated sizes. They practice tracing the insets and matching shapes to cards.
instructions:
1. Present the circle drawer. Remove the largest circle inset.
2. Demonstrate tracing the inside of the frame and then the outside of the inset with two fingers.
3. 'These are all circles, but they are different SIZES.' Grade from largest to smallest.
4. Present the square drawer. Trace and grade.
5. Present the triangle drawer. Trace and grade.
6. Introduce matching cards: solid, thick outline, thin outline.
7. Child matches insets to cards.

items: Geometric cabinet drawers: circles, squares, triangles
Three sets of matching cards per shape
slides.setup_instructions: Place the three drawers on the mat. Have matching cards sorted by shape in separate stacks.

slides.text: 'This cabinet holds flat shapes — let us explore three drawers today.' Open the circle drawer. Remove the largest circle by its knob.
Demonstrate tracing: 'First trace INSIDE the frame with two fingers... then trace AROUND the inset.' Slow, deliberate movements. Child traces.
'All of these are circles, but look — they go from BIG to SMALL. Can you put them in order?' Grade all circles from largest to smallest.
Repeat with squares and triangles. 'How are squares different from circles? Squares have corners and straight sides!'

slides.prompt: Match each shape inset to its card: first the solid card (filled in), then the thick outline, then the thin outline. Can you match all of them?

slides.text: 'You traced and sorted three different shapes in many sizes. Your fingers are learning what shapes feel like!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly trace, grade by size, and match shapes to all three card types?

parent_notes: The geometric cabinet is a cornerstone sensorial material that prepares the child for geometry. The three sets of matching cards progress in abstraction: solid (filled shape), thick outline, thin outline. This mirrors the Montessori principle of moving from concrete to abstract. Tracing with two fingers (index and middle) prepares the hand for writing while building the muscular memory of shape. The child is internalizing properties of shapes — curves vs. straight edges, number of sides, symmetry — all through the hand. If you do not have the full cabinet, you can create paper insets and cards.

title: Phonograms — ee and oo
description: Introduction to the double vowel phonograms 'ee' (as in tree) and 'oo' (as in moon). The child traces sandpaper phonogram cards and builds words with the moveable alphabet.
instructions:
1. Review ai and oa from yesterday.
2. Present 'ee': 'Two e's together say /ee/ as in tree.'
3. Trace the sandpaper card. Three-period lesson.
4. Present 'oo': 'Two o's together say /oo/ as in moon.'
5. Trace and three-period lesson.
6. Build words: tree, see, bee, feet, moon, spoon, food, zoo.
7. Child reads each word. Sort words into 'ee' and 'oo' columns.
materials_needed: Picture cards: tree, bee, feet, moon, spoon, zoo

slides.heading: Phonograms
slides.subheading: ee and oo — Double Vowel Sounds

slides.setup_instructions: Have ee and oo sandpaper cards ready. Set out moveable alphabet and picture cards.

slides.text: 'Yesterday we learned ai and oa. Today we meet two more vowel teams! These ones use the SAME letter twice.'
Present 'ee': 'Two e's side by side say /ee/. Like in TREE and BEE.' Child traces three times. Three-period lesson.
Present 'oo': 'Two o's say /oo/. Like in MOON and SPOON.' Child traces. Three-period lesson.
'Let us build words! T-R-EE. The ee says /ee/.' Build: tree, see, bee, feet. Then: moon, spoon, food, zoo.

slides.prompt: Build 4 'ee' words and 4 'oo' words. Read each one. Sort them into two columns. Match words to picture cards.

slides.text: 'You know four phonograms now: ai, oa, ee, oo! These help you read so many more words.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read words containing ee and oo and sort them correctly?

parent_notes: Double vowel phonograms are satisfying for children because the pattern is visually simple — the same letter twice. Note that 'oo' actually has two common sounds: /oo/ as in moon and /uh/ as in book. For now, introduce only the long /oo/ sound. The short sound will come later. If the child encounters 'book' or 'look,' simply say, 'Sometimes oo says /uh/ instead — English is tricky!' Do not belabor the exception. The moveable alphabet continues to be the primary tool for encoding (building) words, while reading the built words develops decoding skills. Both skills develop together.

title: Golden Bead Multiplication — Practice with Bead Bars
description: The child practices multiplication using colored bead bars. Each bead bar represents a number, making it efficient to 'take a number multiple times' by laying out identical bead bars.
instructions:
1. Review: 'Multiplication means taking the same number several times.'
2. Introduce bead bars: 'This bar has 4 beads — it represents 4.'
3. 'Let us take 4, three times.' Lay out three 4-bars side by side.
4. Count all beads: 4 + 4 + 4 = 12.
5. Record: 4 taken 3 times = 12.
6. Practice: 3 taken 5 times (15), 5 taken 4 times (20), 2 taken 6 times (12).
7. Child selects a bead bar and chooses how many times to take it.

items: Colored bead bars (sets of each number)
slides.setup_instructions: Arrange bead bars by color/number on the mat. Have enough of each number for multiple groups.

slides.text: 'Yesterday we multiplied with golden beads on trays. Today we use bead bars! Each bar is a number.' Show the 4-bar: 'Count the beads — this is 4.'
'Let us take 4, three times.' Lay three 4-bars in a row. 'One group of 4... two groups of 4... three groups of 4.'
'Count all the beads together: 4, 8, 12! Four taken three times equals 12.' Place numeral cards: 4 x 3 = 12.
'Try 3 taken 5 times.' Child lays five 3-bars and counts: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15.

slides.prompt: Choose a bead bar. Decide how many times to take it. Lay them out, count the total, and record the result. Try at least 3 different multiplications!

slides.text: 'Bead bars make multiplication quick — you can see all the groups lined up! You are becoming a multiplier!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child select a bead bar, lay out the correct number of groups, and count to find the product?

parent_notes: The colored bead bars are a bridge between the large golden bead material and abstract multiplication. Each number has its own color (1=red, 2=green, 3=pink, 4=yellow, 5=light blue, 6=purple, 7=white, 8=brown, 9=dark blue, 10=gold). Laying out identical bars in rows makes the concept of equal groups visually clear. The child may naturally begin skip counting (4, 8, 12...) which is wonderful — this is the foundation of times tables. Do not drill facts; let the pattern emerge through repeated concrete experience. Some children enjoy recording their results in a little multiplication book.

title: Animal Kingdom — Vertebrates and Invertebrates
description: Introduction to the first great division of the animal kingdom: animals with backbones (vertebrates) and animals without (invertebrates). The child sorts animal pictures into two groups.
instructions:
1. 'All animals belong to a big family called the Animal Kingdom. Today we learn the FIRST way to sort them.'
2. Feel your own backbone: 'Run your hand down the middle of your back. Feel those bumps? That is your BACKBONE or SPINE.'
3. 'Some animals have a backbone like us — they are called VERTEBRATES.' Show pictures: cat, fish, bird, frog, snake.
4. 'Some animals have NO backbone — they are INVERTEBRATES.' Show: worm, butterfly, jellyfish, spider, snail.
5. Sort picture cards into two groups.
6. 'Which group has MORE animals in the world? Invertebrates — by far!'

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare picture cards of 5+ vertebrates and 5+ invertebrates. Make two label cards. Place on mat.

slides.text: 'The Animal Kingdom is HUGE — millions of different animals! Scientists sort them into groups. The first big question is: Does it have a BACKBONE?'
'Feel your back — those bumps are your backbone! Animals with backbones are called VERTEBRATES.' Show pictures: cat, fish, bird, frog, snake. 'All of these have backbones inside.'
'Animals WITHOUT backbones are called INVERTEBRATES.' Show: worm, butterfly, jellyfish, spider, snail. 'These are soft or have their hard parts on the OUTSIDE.'
'Here is a surprising fact: MOST animals on Earth are invertebrates! Insects alone outnumber all vertebrates combined.'

slides.prompt: Sort the animal picture cards into two groups: Vertebrate and Invertebrate. For each card, ask yourself: does this animal have a backbone inside its body?

slides.text: 'You made the first big division of the Animal Kingdom! Next we will learn the five groups of vertebrates.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the difference between vertebrates and invertebrates and correctly sort at least 8 out of 10 animal cards?

parent_notes: Montessori zoology begins with the big picture — the entire animal kingdom — and progressively narrows. This top-down approach gives children a framework for organizing all future animal knowledge. The vertebrate/invertebrate division is the first branching point. Let the child feel their own spine first — this embodied experience makes the abstract concept concrete. Some children are fascinated to learn that 97% of all animal species are invertebrates! If the child asks about specific animals (Is a shark a vertebrate? What about a crab?), welcome these questions — curiosity drives Montessori learning. A shark has a cartilage skeleton, but it is still a vertebrate. A crab has an exoskeleton and is an invertebrate.

title: Watercolor Painting — Wet on Wet Technique
description: Introduction to wet-on-wet watercolor painting. The child learns to wet the paper first, then apply color, watching how pigments flow and blend on a damp surface.
instructions:
1. 'Today we try a special way to paint. We will make the paper WET first!'
2. Demonstrate preparing the workspace: watercolor paper, paint palette, two water jars, large brush.
3. Dip the large brush in clean water and paint the entire paper with water.
4. 'Now choose a color and touch it to the wet paper. Watch what happens!'
5. The color will spread and bloom. 'On wet paper, the paint moves on its own!'
6. Add a second color near the first — they will blend.
7. Let the child create freely. When finished, lay flat to dry.

items: Two water jars (one for rinsing, one for clean water)
slides.setup_instructions: Cover the workspace. Set out two water jars, paints, and paper. Put on the painting smock.

slides.text: 'Today we paint in a new way! First, we make the whole paper wet with clean water.' Demonstrate brushing water across the entire page.
'Now pick a color. Gently touch your brush to the wet paper...' Watch the color bloom and spread. 'See how it moves on its own? The water carries the paint!'
'Pick a second color. Put it near the first one. Watch them meet and blend! You cannot control exactly what happens — that is the beauty of this technique.'
'If your paper starts to dry, you can add more water with the clean brush. Rinse your brush between colors in the rinsing jar.'

slides.prompt: Create your own wet-on-wet painting. Experiment with different colors meeting each other. What happens when warm colors meet cool colors?

slides.text: Lay your painting flat to dry. Clean your brush, empty the water jars, and wipe down your workspace. Sign your painting when it is dry!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child wet the paper, apply colors, and observe blending? Does the child clean up independently?

parent_notes: Wet-on-wet watercolor is deeply connected to Waldorf and Montessori art education. It develops the child's relationship with color and teaches acceptance of what cannot be fully controlled — a profound life lesson. The paint moves and blends in unexpected ways, which delights children. Use thick paper (140lb or higher) so it does not buckle. Two water jars are essential: one for rinsing the brush, one for clean water to wet the paper. Limit colors to 2-3 initially to avoid muddy results. Primary colors (red, blue, yellow) show the most dramatic blending into secondary colors. Do not direct what the child should paint — process over product is the philosophy here.

title: Embroidery — Introduction to Running Stitch on Fabric
description: The child transitions from sewing cards to actual fabric embroidery. They learn to thread an embroidery needle, tie a knot, and make a running stitch line on burlap or Aida cloth.
instructions:
1. 'You have been sewing beautifully on cards. Today you will sew on REAL fabric!'
2. Show the embroidery hoop and fabric. Demonstrate securing fabric in the hoop.
3. Thread the needle with embroidery floss. Demonstrate tying a knot at the end.
4. Draw a simple straight line on the fabric with washable marker.
5. 'We will use the running stitch you already know: up, down, up, down — following the line.'
6. Demonstrate 3-4 stitches. Then hand to the child.
7. Child stitches along the line. When done, show how to tie off.

slides.setup_instructions: Secure the burlap in the hoop beforehand. Cut a length of floss (about 18 inches). Draw a simple straight line on the fabric with the washable marker.

slides.text: 'You have sewn on cards. Now we move to REAL fabric! This hoop holds the fabric tight so it is easy to sew.' Let the child feel the taut fabric.
Thread the needle: 'Push the floss through the eye of the needle. Pull it through.' Demonstrate tying a knot at the bottom. Child attempts threading.
'Start from the BACK. Push the needle up through the fabric right at the beginning of the line.' Show the first stitch: up through, then down a short distance ahead.
'Up, down, up, down — just like sewing cards, but on real fabric! Follow the line I drew.' Demonstrate 3-4 stitches.

slides.prompt: Continue the running stitch along the line. Try to keep your stitches about the same size. When you reach the end, we will tie off the thread.

slides.text: Show how to tie off: loop under the last stitch and pull tight. 'You just did real embroidery! You can frame this or keep practicing.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child thread a needle, make a running stitch line on fabric, and tie off?

parent_notes: Moving from sewing cards to real fabric is a significant milestone. Burlap or Aida cloth (cross-stitch fabric) is ideal because the weave is loose and visible — the child can see exactly where to put the needle. A small embroidery hoop (4-6 inches) keeps the fabric taut and manageable for small hands. Use a blunt tapestry needle for safety — it passes through loose-weave fabric easily. Thread should be about 18 inches — longer tangles easily. The running stitch is the same one learned on sewing cards, so the child has confidence. In Montessori, sewing develops concentration, fine motor control, patience, and a sense of accomplishment. Display finished work proudly.

title: Puzzle Words — the, a, is, was
description: Introduction to high-frequency 'puzzle words' (sight words) that cannot be sounded out phonetically. The child learns to recognize the, a, is, and was as whole words through multisensory practice.
instructions:
1. 'Most words follow the rules we have learned. But some words are PUZZLES — they do not follow the rules!'
2. Present 'the' on a card. 'This word is THE. It is in almost every sentence!'
3. Trace 'the' in sand tray. Say it three times.
4. Present 'a': 'This tiny word is A. It looks like the letter a but it says /uh/.'
5. Present 'is' and 'was' the same way.
6. Play a matching game: read a sentence strip and find the puzzle word.
7. Practice reading short sentences using puzzle words: 'The cat is big. A dog was here.'
materials_needed: Puzzle word cards: the, a, is, was

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word cards for the, a, is, was. Write 5-6 sentence strips using these words with phonetic words the child can decode.

slides.text: 'You can sound out most words. But some words are tricky — they do not follow the rules. We call them PUZZLE WORDS because they are like little puzzles to remember.'
Hold up 'the.' 'This word is THE. It is the most common word in English! You will see it everywhere.' Trace it in the sand tray three times, saying 'the' each time.
Present 'a,' 'is,' and 'was' the same way. Trace each in the sand tray. Three-period lesson for all four words.
Read sentence strips together: 'The cat is big.' 'A dog was here.' 'The sun is hot.' The child reads the phonetic words and the puzzle words.

slides.prompt: Read the sentence strips. Find and point to each puzzle word. Then build a sentence using the moveable alphabet that includes at least one puzzle word.

slides.text: 'You know four puzzle words: the, a, is, was. These little words are in almost every book you will ever read!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recognize and read the, a, is, and was in isolation and within sentences?

parent_notes: In Montessori language education, phonetically irregular high-frequency words are sometimes called 'puzzle words' or 'sight words.' The term 'puzzle words' is preferred because it implies the word is interesting (a puzzle to figure out) rather than something to memorize by rote (sight). The child should still attempt to sound out these words — 'the' starts with /th/ which they know — but the vowel sound is irregular. Tracing in the sand tray engages muscle memory. Introduce only 3-4 puzzle words per lesson. The sentence strips are crucial: seeing these words in context makes them meaningful. As the child encounters these words repeatedly in reading, recognition becomes automatic.

title: Stamp Game — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori stamp game. The child learns that small stamps can represent units, tens, hundreds, and thousands, providing a more abstract way to work with large numbers.
instructions:
1. 'You know golden beads well. Now I want to show you something new that works the same way but is smaller and easier to carry.'
2. Present the stamp game box. Open it and show the stamps.
3. 'Green stamps with 1 are UNITS. Blue stamps with 10 are TENS. Red stamps with 100 are HUNDREDS. Green stamps with 1000 are THOUSANDS.'
4. 'Build 2,345 with stamps.' Child counts out 2 thousands, 3 hundreds, 4 tens, 5 units.
5. Build several numbers. Compare to golden beads: 'One blue stamp equals one golden ten bar!'
6. Child builds 5 numbers independently.

slides.setup_instructions: Open the stamp game and lay out the stamps sorted by category. Place numeral cards nearby.

slides.text: 'The golden beads are wonderful but big. This box has tiny stamps that do the same job!' Open the stamp game box.
'Green with 1 = units. Blue with 10 = tens. Red with 100 = hundreds. Green with 1000 = thousands. The COLORS match the numeral cards!'
'Build 2,345. Start with the thousands: 1,000... 2,000. Now hundreds: 100, 200, 300. Tens: 10, 20, 30, 40. Units: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.'
'Each stamp represents one bead. This blue 10 stamp is like one golden ten bar. But stamps are quicker to work with!'

slides.prompt: Build these numbers with stamps: 1,234. Then 3,671. Then 4,508. Then choose your own big number and build it!

slides.text: 'The stamp game is a powerful tool! Next time we will use it to add and subtract, just like we did with golden beads.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly build any 4-digit number using the stamp game stamps?

parent_notes: The stamp game is a critical bridge material in Montessori math. It moves the child from the concrete golden beads (where 10 is physically 10 beads on a bar) to a more abstract representation (where 10 is a single stamp marked '10'). This is one step closer to pencil-and-paper arithmetic. The color coding is essential: it matches the Montessori color hierarchy (green=units, blue=tens, red=hundreds, green=thousands) which the child already knows from numeral cards. Children who have worked extensively with golden beads typically transition to the stamp game smoothly because the operations are identical — only the material has changed. Let the child compare: lay a golden ten bar next to a blue 10 stamp.

title: Community Helpers — Doctors and Nurses
description: Exploring the roles of doctors and nurses in our community. The child learns about the tools they use, how they help people, and practices a simple doctor visit role play.
instructions:
1. 'Who do we visit when we are sick or need a checkup? Doctors and nurses!'
2. Show pictures of doctors and nurses at work.
3. Introduce tools: stethoscope, thermometer, bandages, blood pressure cuff.
4. 'Doctors figure out what is wrong — they DIAGNOSE. Nurses help take care of you — they TREAT.'
5. Role play: set up a pretend doctor's office. Child is the doctor.
6. 'Check the patient (stuffed animal). Listen to the heart, take temperature, apply a bandage.'
7. Discuss: 'How do doctors and nurses help our community?'

items: Optional: white shirt as lab coat
slides.setup_instructions: Set up a pretend doctor's office with a chair for the patient (stuffed animal) and medical tools laid out on a tray.

slides.text: 'Today we learn about doctors and nurses — people who help us stay healthy! Have you visited a doctor? What happened?'
'Doctors and nurses use special TOOLS.' Show the stethoscope: 'This listens to your heart and lungs.' Thermometer: 'This checks your temperature.'
'Doctors go to school for a very long time to learn how the body works. Nurses learn to care for patients and help them feel better.'
'Now YOU be the doctor! Your patient (stuffed animal) has a sore tummy. What will you do? Listen with the stethoscope, take temperature, prescribe rest!'

slides.prompt: Set up your doctor's office. Examine your patient. Use each tool. Write a 'prescription' for your patient: rest, water, soup. Take care of your patient!

slides.text: 'Doctors and nurses keep our whole community healthy. They are helpers we can always count on!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 medical tools and explain how doctors and nurses help people?

parent_notes: Community helpers is a Montessori cultural studies topic that builds social awareness and gratitude. When studying doctors and nurses, connect to the child's own experiences — checkups, vaccinations, visits for illness. This normalizes medical visits and reduces anxiety. The role play is particularly valuable: when a child plays 'doctor,' they process their experiences and gain a sense of mastery over something that can feel scary. Use accurate vocabulary: stethoscope, thermometer, diagnosis, treatment. Children are capable of learning real terminology. If possible, visit a pediatrician's office or invite a medical professional to share about their work.

title: Read-Aloud: Curious George Goes to the Hospital
description: Curious George visits the hospital after swallowing a puzzle piece. This story connects to the community helpers theme and helps demystify hospital visits for young children.
instructions:
1. 'Today George goes to the hospital! Have you ever been to a hospital?'
2. Read aloud with expression.
3. Pause when George meets the doctor: 'What tools is the doctor using? We learned about those!'
4. Discuss: 'How did the doctors and nurses help George?'
5. 'George was brave. It is okay to feel scared at the hospital, but the helpers there want to take care of you.'
6. Draw a picture of George at the hospital or design a get-well card.
materials_needed: Curious George Goes to the Hospital by H.A. Rey and Margret Rey

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Curious George Goes to the Hospital

items: Curious George Goes to the Hospital book
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Prepare drawing supplies for the response activity.

slides.text: 'George is curious as always — and this time his curiosity leads him to the hospital! Let us find out what happens.'
Read aloud. When George meets the doctor: 'Look! The doctor is using a stethoscope — just like the one we played with today!'
After reading: 'George swallowed a puzzle piece! That is why we never put small things in our mouths. How did the hospital help him?'

slides.prompt: Make a get-well card for someone — it could be for George, a friend, or a family member. Draw a picture and write a message if you can.

slides.text: 'Hospitals are places where people go to get better. Doctors and nurses are there to help, just like they helped George.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell what happened to George and identify how the medical professionals helped?

parent_notes: This read-aloud pairs perfectly with the community helpers lesson on doctors and nurses. Curious George books are gentle enough for young children while addressing real-life situations. The hospital setting may bring up questions or anxieties — welcome them. Reassure the child that hospitals are safe places with helpers. Making a get-well card extends the theme into practical kindness and is a meaningful writing opportunity. If your child has had a hospital experience, let them share — processing through storytelling is healthy. The H.A. Rey version is the classic, but updated editions are also available.

title: Constructive Triangles — Third Box (Rectangles)
description: Using the third box of constructive triangles, the child discovers that rectangles of different proportions can all be built from two right-angled triangles. This deepens understanding of geometric relationships.
instructions:
1. Present the third box of constructive triangles.
2. 'We have built shapes with triangles before. Today we discover something about RECTANGLES.'
3. Remove a pair of matching right triangles. Show how they form a rectangle when the black lines are matched.
4. 'Two triangles make a rectangle!' Build all the rectangles in the box.
5. 'Are all the rectangles the same? No — some are long and thin, some are short and wide.'
6. Grade the rectangles from widest to narrowest.
7. Child rebuilds all pairs independently.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the third box on the work mat. Ensure all pieces are present and the black lines are visible.

slides.text: 'Remember how we built squares and other shapes from triangles? Today we use this box to build RECTANGLES.'
Take out one pair of matching right triangles. 'Match the black lines together...' Push them together. 'A rectangle! Two triangles always make a rectangle.'
'Now find the next pair. Match their black lines.' Continue building all rectangles. 'How many rectangles did we make?'
'Look at all our rectangles. Are they the same? This one is wide, this one is narrow. But they are ALL rectangles — four sides, four corners.'

slides.prompt: Build all the rectangles from the box. Then put them in order from widest to narrowest. Can you build them without looking at the black lines?

slides.text: 'Every rectangle can be divided into two triangles. Triangles are the building blocks of many shapes!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child construct all rectangles from triangles and grade them by width?

parent_notes: The constructive triangles are among the most elegant Montessori sensorial materials. The third box focuses specifically on rectangles — all built from pairs of right triangles. The key insight is that ANY rectangle can be divided into two right triangles along its diagonal. This is a foundation for later geometry (area of a triangle = half the area of a rectangle). The black lines guide the child at first, but the real learning happens when they can construct without the guide — recognizing which pairs go together by shape and size. Grading the rectangles from wide to narrow is a sensorial exercise in proportion. Some children enjoy tracing the completed rectangles on paper.

title: Reading Short Books — First Phonetic Readers
description: The child reads their first simple phonetic books independently. These small books contain CVC words, blends, and the phonograms they have learned, giving the child the thrill of reading a whole book.
instructions:
1. 'You have been reading words and sentences. Today you will read a WHOLE BOOK!'
2. Present a simple phonetic reader (3-6 pages, 1-2 sentences per page).
3. 'Look at the cover. What do you think this book is about?'
4. Child reads page by page. Help only if they ask or are stuck for more than 10 seconds.
5. For unknown words: 'Sound it out. What does this phonogram say?'
6. Celebrate completing the book! 'You read a whole book by yourself!'
7. Offer a second book if the child wants to continue.
materials_needed: Phonetic readers (Bob Books, Primary Phonics, or similar)
Reading mat or special reading spot

slides.setup_instructions: Choose books that use CVC words, simple blends, and phonograms the child knows (sh, ch, th, ai, oa, ee, oo). Set up a cozy reading spot.

slides.text: 'You have learned so many sounds, phonograms, and words. You are READY to read a real book! Here is your first one.'
Show the cover. 'What do you see? What do you think will happen? Let us open it and find out!' Child reads the title.
Child reads each page aloud. If stuck: 'Sound it out slowly. What does each part say?' Give time — do not jump in too quickly.
After finishing: 'You read a WHOLE BOOK! How does that feel? What was your favorite part?'

slides.prompt: Read the book again — the second time is even easier! Then try the next book. You are a reader now!

slides.text: 'You are officially a book reader! Every great reader started with a small book just like this one.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently read a simple phonetic reader with minimal assistance?

parent_notes: Reading a first book independently is one of the most transformative moments in a child's education. Choose books carefully — they should be decodable using the phonics the child has learned, not relying on pictures or guessing. Bob Books, Primary Phonics, and Montessori-aligned readers work well. The child may read slowly, letter by letter — this is normal and correct. Do NOT rush them or finish words for them. The struggle of sounding out IS the learning. If they get stuck, point to the letters and ask, 'What sound does this make?' After reading, celebrate genuinely. Many children want to read their first book over and over — encourage this! Rereading builds fluency and confidence. This is a milestone worth marking — consider a small certificate or letting the child call a grandparent to read aloud over the phone.

title: Stamp Game — Addition
description: The child uses the stamp game to perform addition with exchange, transferring the golden bead concepts to this more abstract material. The process is identical but uses stamps instead of beads.
instructions:
1. 'Let us add with the stamp game, just like we added with golden beads!'
2. Problem: 1,234 + 2,458.
3. 'Build the first number with stamps: 1 thousand, 2 hundreds, 3 tens, 4 units.'
4. 'Build the second number below it: 2 thousands, 4 hundreds, 5 tens, 8 units.'
5. 'Combine — start with units: 4 + 8 = 12. Exchange 10 unit stamps for 1 ten stamp!'
6. Continue combining tens, hundreds, thousands — exchanging as needed.
7. Read the answer: 3,692. Practice with 2-3 more problems.
materials_needed: Problem cards or paper with addition problems

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the stamp game on the mat. Prepare 3-4 addition problems with 4-digit numbers that require exchanging.

slides.text: 'Remember how we added with golden beads and exchanged? The stamp game works the same way! Let us add 1,234 + 2,458.'
'Build 1,234 in the top row: 1 green thousand stamp, 2 red hundred stamps, 3 blue ten stamps, 4 green unit stamps.'
'Build 2,458 below: 2 thousand stamps, 4 hundred stamps, 5 ten stamps, 8 unit stamps. Now COMBINE! Start with units: 4 + 8 = 12.'
'12 units! Exchange 10 unit stamps for 1 ten stamp. That leaves 2 units. Move to tens: 3 + 5 + 1 (from exchange) = 9 tens.' Continue through hundreds and thousands.

slides.prompt: Try these: 2,356 + 1,487. Then 3,275 + 4,638. Build, combine, exchange, and find each answer!

slides.text: 'You added big numbers with the stamp game! The stamps are just like golden beads but faster to work with.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform 4-digit addition with exchange using the stamp game?

parent_notes: The stamp game addition process is identical to golden bead addition — the child builds two numbers, combines them starting with units, and exchanges when any category reaches 10 or more. The difference is that stamps are more abstract: a single stamp marked '10' replaces a physical ten-bar of 10 connected beads. If the child struggles, go back to golden beads for that problem and then retry with stamps. The key transition is understanding that one stamp can represent a quantity. Most children who have done extensive golden bead work find the stamp game intuitive. Always start combining from units and work left — this mirrors the standard algorithm they will learn later.

title: Five Classes of Vertebrates
description: Building on the vertebrate/invertebrate lesson, the child learns the five classes of vertebrates: fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals. Each class has unique characteristics.
instructions:
1. Review: 'Vertebrates have backbones. Today we learn the FIVE groups of vertebrates.'
2. Present each class with picture cards and a key characteristic:
   - Fish: live in water, breathe with gills, have scales
   - Amphibians: live in water AND land, moist skin, start as tadpoles
   - Reptiles: have dry, scaly skin, lay eggs on land
   - Birds: have feathers, lay eggs, most can fly
   - Mammals: have hair/fur, mothers make milk, born alive (mostly)
3. Sing or chant the five classes.
4. Sort animal cards into five groups.
materials_needed: Animal picture cards (3 per class, 15 total)
Chart or poster of vertebrate classes

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare labels for each class. Gather 3+ picture cards per class. Lay out on a large mat.

slides.text: 'Vertebrates are sorted into five groups. Each group has something special.' Hold up a fish picture. 'FISH live in water and breathe with GILLS instead of lungs.'
'AMPHIBIANS start in water as babies (like tadpoles) and move to land as adults. Frogs and salamanders are amphibians. Their skin is moist!'
'REPTILES have dry, scaly skin. Snakes, lizards, turtles — all reptiles! BIRDS have FEATHERS — they are the only animals with feathers.'
'MAMMALS have hair or fur, and mothers make MILK for their babies. Dogs, cats, whales, and YOU — all mammals!'

slides.prompt: Sort the animal cards into five groups. For each card ask: Does it have gills? Moist skin? Scales? Feathers? Fur? That tells you which group!

slides.text: 'Fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, mammals — five classes of vertebrates! Can you name one animal in each class?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name the five vertebrate classes and correctly sort at least 12 of 15 animal cards?

parent_notes: The five vertebrate classes are a cornerstone of Montessori zoology. The key characteristics to emphasize are: fish (gills, scales, aquatic), amphibians (moist skin, metamorphosis, water/land), reptiles (dry scales, eggs on land), birds (feathers, eggs), mammals (hair/fur, milk, live birth). Some children ask about exceptions — whales are mammals despite living in water, platypuses are mammals that lay eggs. Welcome these questions as signs of critical thinking! A simple chant helps memory: 'Fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, mammals — five classes, five classes!' This work connects to the Great Lessons in later Montessori years (the Coming of Life).

title: Music — Complex Rhythm Patterns with Instruments
description: Exploring complex rhythm patterns with classroom instruments including syncopation, layered rhythms, and call-and-response patterns.
instructions:
1. 'Music has a BEAT — like a heartbeat! Let us find it.' Clap a steady beat together.
2. Introduce instruments: tambourine, rhythm sticks, shaker, triangle.
3. Demonstrate a simple pattern: clap-clap-shake, clap-clap-shake.
4. Child echoes the pattern.
5. Introduce pattern notation: large circle = loud/strong beat, small circle = soft beat.
6. Read a rhythm pattern from the cards. Play it with instruments.
7. Child creates their own pattern. Perform it for you.
materials_needed: Paper and crayons for creating patterns

slides.heading: Music
slides.subheading: Music — Complex Rhythm Patterns with Instruments

items: Percussion instruments: tambourine, rhythm sticks, shaker, triangle
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out instruments on a mat. Prepare 4-5 rhythm pattern cards with large and small circles representing strong and soft beats.

slides.text: 'Put your hand on your chest. Feel your heartbeat? That is a steady BEAT! Music has a beat too.' Clap together: 1, 2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4.
'These instruments make different sounds.' Try each: tambourine (jingle), sticks (click), shaker (shh), triangle (ding). 'Which is your favorite?'
'I will play a pattern. Listen, then copy me!' Play: TAP-TAP-shake, TAP-TAP-shake. Child echoes.
'Look at this card. Big circle means STRONG beat, small circle means soft beat.' Read and play a card pattern together.

slides.prompt: Create your own rhythm pattern! Draw big and small circles on paper. Then play your pattern with an instrument. Perform it for me!

slides.text: Perform each other's rhythm patterns. 'You are a rhythm composer! Put your instruments away carefully — each one has its own spot.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child maintain a steady beat, echo a rhythm pattern, and create their own simple pattern?

parent_notes: Rhythm is the foundation of music education in Montessori. Before melody or harmony, children need to feel and reproduce steady beats and patterns. Echo games (adult plays, child copies) develop auditory memory and motor coordination. The pattern notation with circles is a pre-reading activity for musical notation — the child reads symbols that represent sounds, just as letters represent speech sounds. Let the child explore the instruments freely before structured work. Each instrument has its own technique: hold the triangle by its string, shake the maraca from the wrist, tap rhythm sticks with a bouncing motion. Creating their own patterns gives ownership and creativity within a structured framework.

title: Cooking Project — Fruit Salad
description: The child prepares a fruit salad using multiple fruits, practicing cutting, measuring, and following a recipe. This more complex cooking project builds on the trail mix experience.
instructions:
1. Wash hands. Review the recipe card together: 3 fruits, cut and combined.
2. Wash all fruits. Name each: strawberries, banana, grapes (or seasonal alternatives).
3. Demonstrate hulling a strawberry and cutting into slices.
4. Child cuts strawberries. Then banana (review from earlier lessons).
5. Child halves grapes (adult pre-cuts if needed for safety).
6. Combine all fruit in a bowl. Stir gently with a spoon.
7. Serve in small cups. Clean up all tools and workspace.
materials_needed: 3 types of fruit (strawberries, banana, grapes or seasonal)

slides.setup_instructions: Wash all fruit. Lay out on a tray with cutting board, knife, bowl, and spoon. Have the recipe card visible.

slides.text: 'Today we are making fruit salad! We need to cut three different fruits and combine them. Let us read the recipe first.'
Demonstrate with a strawberry: 'First, remove the green top — this is called HULLING. Then slice it into pieces.' Show slow, controlled cutting.
'Your turn! Hull the strawberries and slice them. When you are done, we will cut the banana — you already know how to do that!'
'For the grapes, we cut them in half. Hold the grape on the board and cut straight down the middle.' Demonstrate. Child halves grapes.

slides.prompt: Cut all the remaining fruit. Put everything into the bowl and stir gently. Scoop fruit salad into serving cups. Enjoy!

slides.text: Clean up: wash the cutting board, knife, bowl, and spoon. Wipe the table. Compost scraps. 'You made a real recipe from start to finish!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently prepare a multi-fruit salad following the recipe card with safe cutting technique?

parent_notes: Fruit salad involves more cutting variety than previous recipes: hulling strawberries, slicing bananas (review), and halving grapes (new skill). Grape halving is particularly important for safety awareness — whole grapes are a choking hazard for younger siblings, so the child learns a practical safety skill. Let the child choose which fruits to include if possible — agency increases engagement. The recipe card should show each step with pictures. This recipe has no cooking, so the child can truly do every step independently. Fruit salad is also a wonderful math connection: 'If we have 6 strawberries and each gets cut into 4 pieces, how many pieces?'

title: Phonogram Review and Word Building
description: Review of all four phonograms learned this week (ai, oa, ee, oo) plus puzzle words (the, a, is, was). The child builds and reads words and sentences combining phonograms and puzzle words.
instructions:
1. 'Let us review our phonograms! What sound do these make?' Flash ai, oa, ee, oo cards.
2. Speed round: show a card, child says the sound.
3. Build words with each phonogram: rain, boat, tree, moon.
4. Add puzzle words: 'Can you read these sentences?'
5. Sentence strips: 'The rain is wet.' 'A boat was on the sea.' 'The tree is green.'
6. Child builds their own sentence with moveable alphabet using phonograms and puzzle words.
7. Read the sentence aloud.
materials_needed: Phonogram cards (ai, oa, ee, oo, sh, ch, th)
Puzzle word cards (the, a, is, was)

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all phonogram cards and puzzle word cards. Prepare sentence strips. Have moveable alphabet ready.

slides.text: 'This week you learned four new phonograms. Let us see if you remember!' Hold up ai: 'What does this say?' Repeat for oa, ee, oo.
'Excellent! Now let us read words.' Show word cards one at a time: rain, coat, seed, food, trail, groan, teeth, spoon.
'Now combine with puzzle words! Read this sentence.' Show: 'The rain is on the road.' Child reads each word.
'Read more!' Show: 'A bee was in the tree.' 'The moon is big.' Celebrate smooth reading!

slides.prompt: Build your own sentence with the moveable alphabet. Use at least one phonogram word and one puzzle word. Then read it to me!

slides.text: 'You can read phonograms, puzzle words, AND sentences! You are reading so well. Keep practicing with your books!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read sentences containing phonogram words and puzzle words fluently?

parent_notes: Friday review is essential for consolidation. The child has learned a lot this week: four phonograms and four puzzle words. The review should feel like a celebration of what they have learned, not a test. If the child hesitates on a phonogram, simply remind them and move on — it will solidify with more exposure. The sentence-building activity is powerful because the child becomes an AUTHOR: they choose the words, construct the meaning, and read their creation. This is writing in its truest sense, even though the child is using moveable alphabet rather than pencil. Save any sentences the child builds — photograph them or transcribe them into a special book.

title: Stamp Game — Subtraction
description: The child uses the stamp game for subtraction with exchange. When there are not enough stamps in a category, the child learns to exchange one stamp from the next higher category for 10 of the current category.
instructions:
1. 'We can subtract with the stamp game too! Let us try 3,542 - 1,267.'
2. Build 3,542 with stamps.
3. 'Start with units: take away 7. But we only have 2! We need to EXCHANGE.'
4. Exchange 1 ten stamp for 10 unit stamps. Now we have 12 units. Take away 7 = 5.
5. Tens: 3 tens (after exchange) - 6 tens. Exchange again from hundreds.
6. Continue through hundreds and thousands.
7. Read the answer: 2,275. Practice with more problems.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the stamp game on the mat. Prepare subtraction problems that require exchanging.

slides.text: 'Addition combines. Subtraction takes away! Let us subtract 1,267 from 3,542. First, build 3,542.'
'Start with units: take away 7. Count your unit stamps — only 2! We need more. EXCHANGE: trade 1 ten stamp for 10 unit stamps.'
'Now you have 12 unit stamps. Take away 7.' Child removes 7 units. '5 units remain. Move to tens: you now have 3 tens. Take away 6. Not enough!'
'Exchange 1 hundred stamp for 10 ten stamps. Now 13 tens, take away 6 = 7 tens. Continue: hundreds, thousands.' Arrive at 2,275.

slides.prompt: Try 4,731 - 2,548. Build the first number. Subtract starting from units, exchanging when needed. Check: does your answer make sense?

slides.text: 'Subtraction with exchange is like the reverse of addition with exchange. You are doing really advanced math!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform 4-digit subtraction with exchange using the stamp game?

parent_notes: Stamp game subtraction with exchange (borrowing) is one of the most important Montessori math lessons. The physical act of trading one ten stamp for 10 unit stamps makes 'borrowing' concrete and logical. The child literally sees that 1 ten equals 10 units — there is nothing mysterious about it. Always start subtracting from units (right to left). If the child forgets to exchange, they will discover they do not have enough stamps — this self-correcting aspect is built into the material. Do not explain the algorithm abstractly; let the hands teach the brain. After many repetitions with the stamp game, the child will eventually be ready for pencil-and-paper subtraction and will already understand what 'borrowing' means.

title: Grace and Courtesy — Telephone Manners
description: The child learns proper telephone manners: how to answer a phone, take a message, make a polite call, and say goodbye. Role play with a toy phone makes this practical and fun.
instructions:
1. 'Telephones help us talk to people far away. Let us learn how to use one politely.'
2. Demonstrate answering: 'Hello, this is the [family name] home. May I ask who is calling?'
3. Demonstrate calling: 'Hello, this is [child name]. May I please speak to [person]?'
4. Practice taking a message: 'They are not here right now. May I take a message?'
5. Role play: you call, child answers. Then switch.
6. Practice leaving a message: name, reason for calling, phone number.
7. 'Always say goodbye and wait for the other person to say goodbye too.'
materials_needed: Two toy phones or old cell phones

slides.setup_instructions: Set up two phones on opposite sides of a table. Have a message pad and pencil ready.

slides.text: 'When the phone rings, we answer politely.' Demonstrate: 'Hello, this is the Smith home. Who is calling please?' Practice three times.
'When YOU call someone, say your name first.' Demonstrate: 'Hello, this is Ana. May I please speak to Grandma?' Practice.
'Sometimes the person is not home. Then you take a MESSAGE.' Write on the pad: who called, what they said, phone number.
'Always say GOODBYE before hanging up. And use a kind voice — the person cannot see your face, so your voice shows your feelings.'

slides.prompt: Let us role play! I will call and you answer. Then you call me. Take a message when I am not available. Practice until it feels natural!

slides.text: 'Now you know how to answer, call, take a message, and say goodbye on the phone. Practice with a real call to a family member this week!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child answer the phone politely, make a call, and take a simple message?

parent_notes: Telephone manners is a classic Montessori grace and courtesy lesson that remains relevant even in the age of texting. The child learns social scripts that reduce anxiety about phone calls and build confidence in communication. Role play is essential — the child needs to practice both sides of the conversation multiple times. Using real (but deactivated) phones makes the practice more authentic than toy phones. After practicing, arrange for the child to make a real call to a grandparent or friend — the transfer from practice to real life is thrilling for the child. Taking a message also involves writing practice: who called, what they said, their number. This is a practical, real-world reason to write.

title: Read-Aloud: Strega Nona by Tomie dePaola
description: A beloved Italian folktale about a magic pasta pot and what happens when Big Anthony does not follow the rules. Themes of listening, responsibility, and consequences connect to practical life.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This story comes from Italy — remember Italy on our Europe map? It looked like a boot!'
2. 'Strega Nona means Grandma Witch in Italian. She has a magic pasta pot!'
3. Read aloud with expression. Pause when Big Anthony discovers the magic words.
4. 'What do you think will happen when Big Anthony uses the pot?' Predict.
5. After the pasta overflows: 'What went wrong? Why did this happen?'
6. Discuss the lesson: 'Why is it important to listen to ALL the instructions, not just part of them?'

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Place the globe nearby to show Italy.

slides.text: 'This story is from Italy — let us find Italy on the map! It looks like a boot. Italian food is famous around the world. This story is about a magic pasta pot.'
Read aloud. When Big Anthony decides to use the pot: 'He only heard PART of the instructions. Is that a good idea?' Let the child predict.
As the town fills with pasta: 'Oh no! What would YOU do? How can they stop it?' Build suspense.

slides.prompt: Draw the funniest part of the story — the town covered in pasta! Or draw what YOU would do if you had a magic pasta pot. What food would yours make?

slides.text: 'Big Anthony learned an important lesson: always listen to ALL the instructions! That is why we follow each step in our work carefully.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why Big Anthony's plan failed and connect it to the importance of following complete instructions?

parent_notes: Strega Nona is a perfect end-of-week read-aloud that connects to multiple curriculum areas: geography (Italy/Europe), practical life (following instructions in cooking), and grace and courtesy (listening carefully). The story's humor — a whole town drowning in pasta — delights children while teaching a serious lesson about responsibility and consequences. The Italian cultural element ties to the puzzle map work this week. If you have time, making simple pasta together after the story brings it to life. Tomie dePaola's illustrations are warm and distinctive. This is the first book in a beloved series — the child may want to read more Strega Nona stories.
